Hello Martin,

Please see below. 

> 
> 1. Definition of modularity: To my =
mind it is not clear, how a module should be defined. Accoording to Kashtan=
 (http://www.pnas.org/content/102/39/13773.abstract), cited by Jeff, modula=
rity is defined as many connections within a module and less connections be=
tween modules. But one could also use the cytoarchitecture (e.g. brodmann a=
reas, cell types / wiring in the hippocampus) as a criteria for measuring t=
he modularity. Obviously, the definition of modules biases the search for t=
hem.
> 
> 
Another definition I use is a functionally encapsulated unit, wi=
th high intra-modular interactions and few inter-modular interactions. That=
 is consistent with the Kashtan and Alon definition you mention, but it is =
not specific to networks. See the Lipson paper we cite for a longer discuss=
ion of these definitions. 

How would using the cytoarchitecture change our=
 measure of modularity? My guess is that you'd end up with roughly the same=
 identified modules, but that may be because I don't understand what you ar=
e suggesting. 

> 2. Emergence of modularity: independent from the definiti=
on, I don't see, why network modules should evolve in different ways like o=
ther organic structures. To my mind, the same principles that lead to the f=
ormation of global patterns in the organism contribute also to the formatio=
n of specific brain structures (favoring to my mind the cytoarchitectural p=
erspective).
> 
Did you get the impression from somewhere that I believe th=
at network modules evolve differently than modules in other structures? I h=
ave not stated that (that I can recall). I think it is possible that this c=
onnection cost idea may also apply to many different types of structures (e=
.g. organs and kinematic linkages). 

> Following this perspective, it seem=
 to me that different spatial locations of sensor and motor systems contrib=
ute already to the formation of different modules emerging at these systems=
. This raises the question: what could be a good starting organism to inves=
tigate this hypothesis? I found this article very interesting, as it descri=
bes a possible transition from decentralized networks to a CNS with modules=
:
> 
> "Early Central Nervous System Evolution: An Era of Skin Brains?"
> h=
ttp://www.nature.com/nrn/journal/v4/n8/abs/nrn1175.html
> 
> 3. Self-organi=
zing mechanisms determine the number of connections: This review gave me a =
new perspective on neural networks as it convinced me how important structu=
ral plasticity is: 
> "Using theoretical models to analyse neural developme=
nt"
> http://www.nature.com/nrn/journal/v12/n6/abs/nrn3031.html
> (e.g. see=
. Fig. 6)
> 
> The main message: neurons find on their own an equilibrium b=
etween spiking and resting. If a neuron spikes too less, the number of conn=
ections increases, if it spikes too often, connections die. This means, the=
 number of connections is dynamically selected to make (as a side-effect) e=
ach neuron as informative as possible. (Maybe this is the way to use the en=
coding in order to constrain the number of connections, as suggested by Ken=
?)
> 
> 
That is an interesting idea! 

> Clearly influenced by the cited a=
rticles, my humble and unproven opinion is that modularity emerges as a sid=
e-effect of the fact that sensors and motors already represent something li=
ke modules and that self-organizing mechanisms and mechanisms to evolve and=
 alter global patterns contribute to the elaboration of these modules.
> 
>=
 
The brain is a huge collection of 100 trillion connections and billions o=
f neurons=85very few of those directly connect to external sensors and actu=
ators. Do you think that spatial segregation of sensors and actuators drive=
s the evolution of modularity within the brain itself (e.g. in the neo-cort=
ical column, a module that is repeated over and over inside the cortex)? 

=
> To avoid some misunderstandings: I think, using connection cost in a fitn=
ess function is absolutely valid and provides some useful insights (therefo=
re I found Jeffs article very interesting). My point is just: one has to be=
 aware that the number of connections in a network underlies some factors w=
orth considering. :-)
> 
>
